newsitem.title: CHINA: China, U.S. to survey World War Two crash site.
newsitem.headline: China, U.S. to survey World War Two crash site.

text.p: Officials from China and the United States will jointly investigate the site of the crash of a U.S. bomber in World War Two that was found in a remote Chinese valley in October, the China Daily said on Saturday.
The B-24 bomber and the remains of several crew members were found in a remote valley in China's southwestern Guangxi region in early October by two farmers collecting medicinal herbs.
Officials from the two countries will begin their investigation at the site in January, the newspaper said.

Chinese president Jiang Zemin gave U.S. President Bill Clinton photographs of the wreckage and a videotape of the crash site when they met last month at the summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Manila.

Earlier this month, Chinese Defence Minister Chi Haotian handed over two dog tags recovered from the site during a meeting in Washington with U.S. Secretary of Defence William Perry, China Daily said.
The names on the tags were those of two of 10 people on board a bomber that went missing on August 31, 1944 while on a run from an airstrip at Liuzhou in Guangxi, the newspaper said.
The plane disappeared on its way back to the base after attacking Japanese warships in a Taiwan port, it said.
